Topic.Title: Windows XP end of life

Message.Msg: I love XP. I have one desktop on XP and my new desktop in Win 7. I purposely avoided Win 8 because it was new and a new OS is not something I want to deal with. My XP machine is still great for internet and word processing. Personally, I plan to have a 3 screens. A desktop for real work and games, a tablet for couch-based reading (new/books), and a phone. How is 3 screens powered by INTC worse than buying 1, even if "margins will be cannibalized." February next year, I plan to have a Win 8 tablet and phone. The Apple ecosystem is too restrictive for me, I have an iPhone. And with WiDi, my TV becomes screen #4. The analysts need to start counting screens, not traditional computers. Three screens is better than one. I truly think reality will come fast and harsh for the bears.

Message.Title: The Smartwatch Revolution Isn't Waiting
Message.Msg: The leading tech companies are maneuvering for a titanic battle to win market share in the upcoming battle for smartwatch buyers. In a recent Google infomercial (also known as the movie The Internship), the main characters, played by Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson, lose their jobs as wristwatch salesmen because “everything is computerized now.” In desperation, they do the only logical thing, which is to try out for Google internships. That idea was as unlikely to succeed as it was unrealistic. (The only less realistic thing about the movie was its depiction of a Google phone tech support help line.) Instead, our bumbling heroes should have stuck it out in the wristwatch racket, because watches are about to come back in a major way. And, yes, everything is computerized now. But the wristwatch is doomed, right? After all, nobody wears watches anymore. Who in their right mind would sell a wristwatch that connects to the Internet, providing the user with notifications, incoming chat and social messages and possibly runs apps? Nobody, really, except for Apple, Google, Microsoft, Intel, Sony, Samsung, LG and at least a dozen international startups. From Datamation

Topic.Title: The Smartwatch Revolution Isn't Waiting

Message.Msg: Smartwatches Getting Smarter, But Silicon Valley Is Late! The conventional impulse has been for everyone to wait for rumored or announced smartwatches from the tech giants. Yes, the rumors and accompanying factoids (such as patents) are plausible. Intel’s CTO Justin Rattner said this week that Intel is working on “novel display devices” that live on your wristand feed you smartphone information. Rumors persist that Intel could be working with Apple on their rumored iWatch. Google’s Android group is reportedly working on a smartwatch, presumably one that takes advantage of service infrastructure from the company’s Glass project. Samsung executive VP Lee Young Hee confirmed in March that the company is “working very hard” to produce a smartwatch. The Korea Times reported in March that tech giant LG is also working on a smartwatch, as well as a competitor to Google Glass. Another report emerging in April says that former Microsoft Xbox and Kinect team members had already built a prototype Microsoft smartwatchthat connects to the company’s Surface tablet. If the idea of a Microsoft smartwatch sounds unlikely, you should know that Microsoft pioneered the concept back in the 1990s. I personally owned a Timex Datalink watch, co-developed by Microsoft, which magically synchronized with a PC when you held it up to the screen and ran the sync app. Flashing on-screen lights transmitted the data. So, yes, it appears likely that pretty much every major company that makes consumer electronics is working furiously on the development of a smartwatch. But the world isn’t waiting. Sony doesn’t just have a rumored or announced smartwatch, they’ve already shipped one, open-sourced it and announced a second version.

Topic.Title: The Smartwatch Revolution Isn't Waiting

Message.Msg: If you were thinking that the smartphone revolution isn’t going to happen, this column should change your opinion. The forms, features and functions of these watches are powerful, useful and varied. And yes, when the consumer electronics giants finally jump in with their offerings, and start pouring millions of dollars into marketing and advertising, this category is going to get very real starting this year’s holiday season. [And we know that Intel is in the mix someplace...]

Message.Title: Thinking About Earnings
Message.Msg: One very solid part of earnings we can look forward to in earnings is in the tablet area. Current numbers are going to show solid growth and guidance should be even better. The two wildcards in earnings are SmartWatches and Intel's Web TV Project. Nothing has been factored into guidance for either and if either should break-out it could have a very positive effect...

Message.Title: Intel is a great buy
Message.Msg: Intel will explode to the upside in the second half. - Haswell will spur PC pent-up refresh cycle as corporation adopt Windows 8 - Gross margins will get back above 60% as there will be no more excess capacity charges (factories utilization will be back to normal) nor impact of higher factory startup costs. - Bay Trail tablets will have "clear performance and/or power consumption" advantage - More design wins for smartphones with CloverTraill+. Don't be surprise to see phones with CloverTrail+ with LTE 4G support hitting US markets this year! - PCs hybrids will continue to blur the lines between tablets and PCs and more and more people will opt for a PC hybrid as 'best of both world' value proposition takes hold. - Possible huge foundries deals with Cisco and others - Possible smartwatch products in collaboration with Apple or Samsung or others - Web TV could turn out to be a game-changer

Message.Title: The advantage of having a superior product
Message.Msg: Bay Trail will have "twice the performance at the same power level or 4.3x less power at the same performance" compared to projected competitors including the snapdragon 800. Tablets with Intel inside will have a distinct competitive advantage over those that don't. The Intel bandwagon is starting to roll...

We are still waiting on Haswell refresh of the following products: MS Surface Pro Lenovo Yoga Lenovo Helix MacBook Pros More incredible products to come with launch of Y-series Haswell and Bay Trail!

Message.Title: An important quote from a MSFT article. 2.35 billion devices projected in 2013.
Message.Msg: This is what I've been saying for a while. It's all about the screens. INTC shorts and analysts need to stop counting PCs and start counting screens, or face dire consequences. And the truth will be 3 screen per person (not counting developing nations), a large screen for work and games, a smaller screen for books, news, and travel, and a phone. "No one is counting on growth of the traditional PC and notebook this year. Gartner Inc. said this week that it forecasts PC and notebook shipments to drop 10.6% to 305 million units in 2013, down from 2012. It is interesting to note that Gartner also included a new forecast in its report for “worldwide devices,” which combines the forecast for PCs, tablets and mobile phones. When including mobile phones and tablets with PCs, devices are projected to reach 2.35 billion units in 2013, a 5.9% increase from 2012, Gartner said."

Topic.Title: Will it lag the markets

Message.Msg: If the time frame you use is the last 13 years, then you are making the right decision. If you look at the past 12 months, several substantial things have changed. The short interest in Intel is at near record highs. Intel is buying back shares and reducing the share float. That means that 1 share buys more of the company. Intel has just introduced a new product line (Haswell) that has market disrupting low power, high performance. Intel has just introduced a family of 60-core CPUs (PHI) that are the foundation of the HPC supercomputer market. Intel has a number of new introductions pending (Bay Trail-T and Bay Trail-P and 14nm process production) that will lower the cost per transistor by 30% to 40%. Please act on your research analysis to the extent you feel comfortable.

Message.Msg: "For someone to say that Apple or any other fabless semiconductor company has signed a foundry deal for 10nm is just silly. 10nm negotiations have just started and will absolutely hinge on who delivers 14/16nm FinFETs as promised and at what price." Hey, at last, you have useful information and it's something good for Intel for a change. #1. The 28nm node flaws haven't been worked out yet. If they have they would be all over the street. #2. 20nm is a talking point right now, though it's been taped out as you have said there have been no leaked benchmarks. Trust me, ARMH would talking about this night and day. #3. 14/16nm finfet is a far off dream. Yes people may be talking about it right now ,but as you said everybody is non-committal. It must be at least a good two years away if not longer before a functioning prototype is ready. I know TSMC must be putting on it's best gameface, letting people know that 20nm is almost here and 16nm is next year. As far as having the right product (14nm finfet) right now (or the soonest possible) at the right price that will be Intel. Welcome to the new era of the semiconductor industry where empty promises and vaporware don't go as far as they did two years ago. I like that you eluded to this in your post, it's a period of putting up or shutting up. Can't wait to see what TSMC can really do. I have my doubts, waiting to see real products to prove me wrong.

Message.Title: Did Microsoft just preview a Haswell Surface at Build?
Message.Msg: I’ve been reviewing the Build keynote from this afternoon and I’ve stumbled onto something that is a little bit mysterious. During Antoine Leblond’s developer address during the keynote (around the 48 minute mark), he used a Surface Pro machine to preview new Visual Studio development tools on power consumption. At face value, this information isn’t particularly shocking. However, when he revealed a demo app’s power consumption, Visual Studio claimed that the app would last 9.17 hours (that’s 9 hours and 10 minutes) on battery- a feat that the current Surface Pro would definitely not be able to achieve with current estimates. Though battery estimates have never been an exact science, this number is definitely out of the realm of possibility for the Surface Pro, which can at most last for a paltry 4 hours. The Surface RT, despite stellar battery life, is definitely not equipped to run Visual Studio. This estimate leads me to believe that Microsoft just teased the new Surface Pro with Haswell, right in plain sight. I’ll update this post accordingly should I receive anymore information. The video in question is after the break. From winsource

Message.Title: U.S. oil output is poised to surpass Saudi Arabia’s in the next decade
Message.Msg: Bloomberg U.S. oil output is poised to surpass Saudi Arabia’s in the next decade, making the world’s biggest fuel consumer almost self-reliant and putting it on track to become a net exporter, the International Energy Agency said. “Around 2017, the U.S. will be the largest oil producer of the world, overtaking Saudi Arabia,” IEA Chief Economist Fatih Birol said at a press conference in London today. “This is of course a major development and definitely will have significant implications.” The Energy Department forecasts that U.S. production of crude and other liquid hydrocarbons, which includes biofuels, will average 11.4 million barrels per day next year. That would be a 40-year high for the U.S. and just below Saudi Arabia's output of 11.6 million barrels. Citibank forecasts U.S. production could reach 13 million to 15 million barrels per day by 2020, helping to make North America "the new Middle East The United States will still need to import lots of oil in the years ahead. Americans use 18.The United States will still need to import lots of oil in the years ahead. Americans use 18.7 million barrels per day. But thanks to the growth in domestic production and the improving fuel efficiency of the nation's cars and trucks, imports could fall by half by the end of the decade. 7 million barrels per day. But thanks to the growth in domestic production and the improving fuel efficiency of the nation's cars and trucks, imports could fall by half by the end of the decade. But when America hits 15 million per day in production, the use will have fallen to 11 million thanks to conversion of trucks to Natural gas. This will make America a large exporter of oil by 2020. All this after we heard drill baby drill from the GOP in their losing election bid against Obummer. Comical now looking at them and their pathetic rage. He is not American or at least not born in America. He is a commi. He is a N E G R O. Oh my freaking god. Like we did not notice? HAAA HAAA

Message.Title: QCOM: RBC Cuts Target to $72 as Intel Mobile Prospects Rise
Message.Msg: QCOM: RBC Cuts Target to $72 as Intel Mobile Prospects Rise By Tiernan Ray RBC Capital‘s Mark Sue today reiterates an Outperform rating on shares of Qualcomm (QCOM), while warning that the shares could see their foward P/E multiple, currently at 13, compress as competitor Intel (INTC) makes gains in mobile computing. Sue, who also has an Outperform rating on shares of Intel, and a $29 price target, sees the chip giant’s newest, and forthcoming, Atom chips for mobile devices finally “ready for prime time” as the company makes gains in power efficiency after losing out for years to Qualcomm and other chip makers using rival designs from ARM Holdings (ARMH). “The myth of ARM’s power advantage may dissolve quickly, perhaps even before Intel pushes Atom to leading edge,” writes Sue: Expect Intel’s Atom-based mobile processors to become increasingly adopted in the marketplace, driven by improving performance/power dynamics, and ahead of upcoming Silvermont (22nm tri-gate, late 2013) and Airmont (14nm, 2014) launches with LTE enablement. Intel’s win with Saltwell’s Clover Trail+ (32nm) on Samsung [Electronics's (005930KS) 10" Galaxy Tab 3 affirms the strides in mobile that the company has made [...] Intel believes that its dual-core Silvermont offers between 1.4x and 2.1x the performance at 1.6x to 3.1x lower power vs. select quad-core ARM solutions. We await third-party performance reviews in order to have more conviction on the metrics Intel has presented. Nevertheless, the significant improvements in power and performance should allow Intel to become increasingly competitive in the mobile ecosystem. Intel’s Silvermont joins ARM’s Cortex A15 in terms of delivering out-of-order execution. The impact for Intel is some loss of notebook revenue, as that market cools, but ultimately growth in Intel’s combined notebook and tablet/smartphone revenue: The Semis team’s analysis suggests that Intel’s combined notebook (performance processors) and smartphone/tablet (Ato

Message.Title: Intel Seen Gaining Mobile Market Share With New Chips
Message.Msg: [The word is spreading and the news out of the Microsoft Conference has been very positive. WinTel is going to be ramping up...] Upcoming Intel processors are expected to become popular in mobile devices and more than offset a decline in notebook chip sales, RBC Capital analyst Mark Sue said in a research report Thursday. Sue said the improved performance and power dynamics of new versions of Intel's Atom line of processors should help it increase its market share in the mobile market. An indication of that is the recent win with Samsung, which is using Intel's Clover Trail chip in a version of its Galaxy Tab 3, as IBD reported. RBC expects sales of Atom chips in the mobile category to jump to $3.7 billion in 2016, from just $380 million this year. Intel plans to ship a newer version of its Atom processor, the Silvermont, in late 2013, followed by Airmont in 2014. Intel will gain in the market where Qualcomm (QCOM) and licensees of ARM Holdings (ARMH) have dominated. "The market is growing and there are ample opportunities for Qualcomm to gain an incremental footprint," Sue said. Qualcomm customers include most all of the major smartphone makers, including Samsung and Apple (AAPL). Besides that, Qualcomm has a royalty business on its mobile technologies that provides about 75% of its earnings. "Customers typically want choice when it comes to smartphones and tablet computers, and it was inevitable that Intel and others would get some design wins," wrote Sue. Smartphone sales are expected to rise 26% this year to 870 million units worldwide. That pace is expected to slow as the smartphone market becomes increasingly saturated, but there will still be opportunities for Intel, the report said. The increased commoditization of the mobile market "allows inroads for Intel, as they benefit from growth in mainstream product categories where price and performance are required to win," Sue wrote. From IBD

Topic.Title: Intel Seen Gaining Mobile Market Share With New Chips

Message.Msg: "Wells Fargo analyst David Wong, in a report Wednesday, also looked positively on Intel's Atom line of processors, saying its share of tablet processors could rise to 5% this year from just 1% last year." From IBD

Message.Title: Intel Seen Gaining Mobile Market Share With New Chips
Message.Msg: Intel Seen Gaining Mobile Market Share With New Chips By BRIAN DEAGON, INVESTOR'S BUSINESS DAILY Posted 01:46 PM ET Upcoming Intel (INTC) processors are expected to become popular in mobile devices and more than offset a decline in notebook chip sales, RBC Capital analyst Mark Sue said in a research report Thursday. Sue said the improved performance and power dynamics of new versions of Intel's Atom line of processors should help it increase its market share in the mobile market. An indication of that is the recent win with Samsung, which is using Intel's Clover Trail chip in a version of its Galaxy Tab 3, as IBD reported. RBC expects sales of Atom chips in the mobile category to jump to $3.7 billion in 2016, from just $380 million this year. Intel plans to ship a newer version of its Atom processor, the Silvermont, in late 2013, followed by Airmont in 2014. Intel will gain in the market where Qualcomm (QCOM) and licensees of ARM Holdings (ARMH) have dominated. "The market is growing and there are ample opportunities for Qualcomm to gain an incremental footprint," Sue said. Qualcomm customers include most all of the major smartphone makers, including Samsung and Apple (AAPL). Besides that, Qualcomm has a royalty business on its mobile technologies that provides about 75% of its earnings. "Customers typically want choice when it comes to smartphones and tablet computers, and it was inevitable that Intel and others would get some design wins," wrote Sue. Smartphone sales are expected to rise 26% this year to 870 million units worldwide. That pace is expected to slow as the smartphone market becomes increasingly saturated, but there will still be opportunities for Intel, the report said. The increased commoditization of the mobile market "allows inroads for Intel, as they benefit from growth in mainstream product categories where price and performance are required to win," Sue wrote. Wells Far

Topic.Title: Why Intel Will Beat Earnings Estimates

Message.Msg: The news has been overwhelmingly positive. On Silvermont, Haswell, Computex, Mac upgrades, product releases and the Samsung deal. This will likely translate into larger orders and shipments. And probably already has. I would expect an increase in guidance as the second half of the year is looking much better now with back-to-school and holiday sales. With 14nm FinFET production a mere six months away I would expect it to start to affect the equation even for the nimrods on Wall Street. I expect a moderate beat and improved guidance. The newest dynamic is on the Microsoft front. We can expect better than anticipated growth in Windows 8/8.1 adoption. Two factors will be of major import: 1.) Dual boot. This is going to be a huge driver going forward, allowing Android applications to supplement full Windows capabilities. 2.) The XP upgrade wave. This wave will really ramp up in the next six months. The tablet news is going to be solid and improving. Better performance and longer battery life. A vast array of form factors. It's already fun, exciting and entertaining and it's going to consistently get better over the next year. Intel is going to be a major force in tablets. The economic recover is definitely going to help. Things continue to improve. This earnings call should confirm what we already know. Intel is getting ready to break things open...

Topic.Title: Mr Weaver, he huffed and he pumped and the stock is up 5c.

Message.Msg: No matter how much pumping, no matter how much bashing, the fact remains that INTC is just a chip company that is as susceptible, if not more so, than any stock to the ebbs and flows of economic cycles. To endlessly and tirelessly pump INTC as Waldo has at least since 2010 when it was 24, now 24.05 is as foolish as constantly bashing it. INTC could well be far below 19 in 3 years, or it could be at 40.00. Neither posting articles about #$%$ Tracey watches or about the end of pc's is going to change the fact that the market ebbs and flows, The trick is to try to realize gains in both directions. Sometimes right, sometimes wrong, but never, ever fixated only on one direction. (Wally's biggest flaw, three years for .O5) And that's a shame for someone who's 60 plus and should know better. The market creates opportunities in both directions. Ignoring that fact is as senseless and as futile and juvenile as constant pumping or bashing is..

Topic.Title: Why Intel Will Beat Earnings Estimates

Message.Msg: " Dual boot. This is going to be a huge driver going forward, allowing Android applications to supplement full Windows capabilities." I can see having "Dual Boot" will give any tablet OEMs a big edge. My $$$ question is: besides Intel, who else is better position to tackle this market segment? Intel has tons of experience with Windows. They are now getting into Android. Going forward, they are going to be a formidable competitor in this segment, no doubt...

Topic.Title: Why Intel Will Beat Earnings Estimates

Message.Msg: Even if their current quarter's earning don't have good showing (yet), I am sure they will provide better guidance for the next two quarters. Either way, INTC is a strong buy *NOW*.
